title: SOLAS II-2/Reg 3 & 9.2.3: Space Category Definitions for Fire Integrity Tables

=== SOLAS II-2/Reg 3 & 9.2.3: Space Category Definitions ===
=== Purpose: Define space categories used in fire integrity Tables 9.1–9.8 ===

Category (1) — Control stations:
  Definition: Spaces containing the ship’s navigating equipment, radio equipment, main fire control stations, centralized fire recording or fire control stations, machinery control rooms, including safety-related equipment rooms.
  Examples: Wheelhouse/bridge, radio room, fire control station, emergency generator room, emergency switchboard room.
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (1)

Category (2) — Corridors:
  Definition: Corridors, lobbies and halls used as escape routes or general access passages.
  Examples: Main corridor, lobby, hall, stairway landing.
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (2)

Category (3) — Accommodation spaces:
  Definition: Living quarters, offices, hospitals, recreation rooms, pantries containing NO cooking appliances, similar low-fire-risk habitable spaces.
  Examples: Crew cabin, officers’ lounge, mess room, hospital, office, pantry (without stove).
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (3)

Category (4) — Stairways:
  Definition: Interior stairways, lifts and escalators (other than those entirely within machinery spaces) and their enclosures.
  Examples: Main stairway enclosure, lift shaft, stairway trunk.
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (4)

Category (5) — Service spaces (low risk):
  Definition: Lockers, store rooms, workshops, pantries without cooking appliances, laundries, similar spaces of small fire risk.
  Examples: Bosun’s store, linen locker, workshop, laundry, provision room.
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (5)

Category (6) — Machinery spaces of Category A:
  Definition: Spaces containing internal combustion machinery used for main propulsion or for other purposes where the total output is not less than 375 kW, or any oil-fired boiler or oil fuel unit.
  Examples: Main engine room, generator room (>375 kW), boiler room, fuel purifier room.
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (6)

Category (7) — Other machinery spaces:
  Definition: Spaces containing machinery and electrical equipment other than Category (6).
  Examples: Steering gear room, bow thruster room, stabilizer room, small auxiliary engine room.
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (7)

Category (8) — Cargo spaces:
  Definition: All spaces used for cargo (including cargo oil tanks) and trunks to such spaces.
  Examples: Cargo hold, container hold, cargo tank, cargo trunk. For tankers: cargo pump room (see Reg 9.2.4).
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (8)

Category (9) — Service spaces (HIGH risk):
  Definition: Galleys, pantries CONTAINING COOKING APPLIANCES, paint lockers, lamp rooms, flammable liquid store rooms.
  Examples: Main galley, officers’ galley, paint locker, lamp room, chemical store.
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (9)

Category (10) — Open decks:
  Definition: Open deck spaces and enclosed promenades, no source of ignition and with adequate ventilation.
  Examples: Weather deck, open poop deck, enclosed promenade.
  Related requirements: Tables 9.1–9.8 row/column (10). Generally no fire integrity requirement against open decks.

Category (11) — Cargo spaces with high fire risk (cargo ships):
  Definition: For cargo ships only — open-top container spaces, open ro-ro cargo spaces, or cargo oil tank areas.
  Examples: Open ro-ro cargo area, weather-deck container stacks, tanker cargo tank on-deck area.
  Related requirements: Tables 9.5/9.6/9.7/9.8 row/column (11)

ADDITIONAL CATEGORIES for Passenger Ships (>36 pax) — Tables 9.1/9.2:
  Category (12): Tanks, voids, and auxiliary machinery spaces with little or no fire risk.
  Category (13): Cargo spaces and deck areas on ro-ro ships.
  Category (14): Vehicle and ro-ro cargo spaces.

CRITICAL DISTINCTIONS:
- A galley/kitchen WITH cooking equipment = Category (9) HIGH RISK
- A pantry WITHOUT cooking equipment = Category (3) or (5) LOW RISK
- This distinction directly affects fire integrity rating (e.g., galley vs corridor = A-0 on cargo ships, but pantry vs corridor = B-0)

USAGE INSTRUCTION: Use these category definitions when looking up values in Tables 9.1–9.8 for fire integrity.

(2) Corridors
(3) Accommodation spaces (low fire risk)
(4) Stairways
(5) Service spaces (low risk)
(6) Machinery spaces of Category A
(7) Other machinery spaces
(8) Cargo spaces

(10) Open decks
(11) Sanitary and similar spaces
(12) Tanks, voids and auxiliary machinery spaces with little or no fire risk
(13) Cargo deck spaces on ro-ro ships

title: SOLAS II-2/Reg 10: Firefighting Systems — Fire Main, Extinguishers, Fixed CO2, Foam, Sprinkler
text:
=== SOLAS II-2/Reg 10: Firefighting Systems Requirements ===
=== Applicable to: All ships ===

10.2 — FIRE MAIN AND HYDRANTS:
  Required equipment:
  - At least 2 fire pumps (not counting emergency fire pump)
  - Pressure at most remote hydrant: ≥0.27 MPa (passenger) / ≥0.25 MPa (cargo)
  - International shore connection: standard flange dimensions per SOLAS
  - Fire hoses: sufficient length to reach any part of each space
  Additional requirements:
  - Emergency fire pump required (independent power source)
  - Fire main isolation valves to allow sectional operation

10.3 — PORTABLE FIRE EXTINGUISHERS:
  Required equipment:
  - Cargo ships: At least 5 portable extinguishers in accommodation/service spaces
  - Passenger ships: sufficient quantity at each fire station
  - Spare charges: 100% spare for first 10 extinguishers, 50% for remainder
  Types:
  | Type | Suitable For |
  | Foam/Water spray | Class A (solids) |
  | CO2 | Class B (liquids), Class C (electrical) |
  | Dry chemical | Class B and C |
  | AFFF foam | Class A and B |

10.4 — FIXED FIRE-EXTINGUISHING SYSTEMS (general):
  Required in:
  - Machinery spaces of Category A
  - Cargo pump rooms on tankers
  - Vehicle/ro-ro cargo spaces
  - Cargo holds (where required)

10.5 — FIXED GAS (CO2) FIRE-EXTINGUISHING SYSTEMS (+ FSS Code Ch.5):
  Required equipment:
  - CO2 free gas volume ≥40% of gross volume of largest machinery space
  - OR ≥35% including casing volume
  - 85% of required CO2 quantity released within 2 minutes
  - Audible alarm BEFORE CO2 release in any manned space
  - Time delay between alarm and release sufficient for crew evacuation
  - Two independent means of control (in and outside protected space)
  - Cargo spaces: sufficient CO2 for 30% of gross volume of largest cargo hold

10.6 — FIXED FOAM FIRE-EXTINGUISHING SYSTEMS:
  - For machinery spaces: approved foam concentrate
  - For helicopter facilities: AFFF foam system
  - Foam quantity: sufficient for 5 minutes operation

10.7 — FIXED PRESSURE WATER-SPRAYING SYSTEMS:
  - Alternative to CO2 or foam for machinery spaces
  - Water application rate: ≥5 L/m²/min for machinery spaces

10.8 — AUTOMATIC SPRINKLER SYSTEMS:
  - Required in passenger ship accommodation and service spaces
  - Sprinkler heads: max spacing per FSS Code
  - Water supply: sufficient for 1 hour simultaneous operation

10.9 — FIXED FIRE DETECTION AND ALARM:
  - Required in machinery spaces of Category A
  - Smoke detectors: max coverage area per FSS Code Ch.9
  - Heat detectors: for spaces with anticipated ambient heat

10.10 — FIREMAN’S OUTFIT:
  - Cargo ships: at least 2 sets
  - Passenger ships: at least 4 sets (one per main vertical zone)
  - Each set: protective clothing, SCBA (30 min), fireproof lifeline, fire axe, portable lamp

OIL TANKER SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS (SOLAS II-2/10.8-10.9):
  - Fixed deck foam system covering entire cargo deck area
  - Foam monitors: minimum 2, capable of reaching any part of cargo deck
  - Inert gas system: required for all tankers ≥20,000 DWT
  - Cargo tank venting through P/V valves or equivalent

LOOKUP INSTRUCTION: First identify ship type and space, then find matching section for equipment requirements.

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- CO2 alarm must always sound BEFORE release in manned spaces
- International shore connection must be accessible from both sides
- Fire pump test: key survey item — measure pressure at most remote hydrant

title: MARPOL Annex VI Reg 13: NOx Emission Limits — Tier I/II/III
text:
=== MARPOL Annex VI Reg 13: NOx Emission Limits ===
=== Applicable to: All marine diesel engines >130 kW (excluding emergency engines) ===

Tier I — Ship construction date: 1 Jan 2000 to 31 Dec 2010:
  n < 130 rpm: 17.0 g/kWh
  130 ≤ n < 2000 rpm: 45.0 × n^(−0.2) g/kWh
  n ≥ 2000 rpm: 9.8 g/kWh

Tier II — Ship construction date: 1 Jan 2011 onwards:
  n < 130 rpm: 14.4 g/kWh
  130 ≤ n < 2000 rpm: 44.0 × n^(−0.23) g/kWh
  n ≥ 2000 rpm: 7.7 g/kWh

Tier III — Ship construction date: 1 Jan 2016 onwards (IN ECA ONLY):
  n < 130 rpm: 3.4 g/kWh
  130 ≤ n < 2000 rpm: 9.0 × n^(−0.2) g/kWh
  n ≥ 2000 rpm: 2.0 g/kWh

CRITICAL NOTES:
1. Tier III applies ONLY when operating in a NOx Emission Control Area (NECA)
2. Outside NECA, Tier II applies (for post-2011 ships)
3. 'n' = rated engine speed in revolutions per minute (rpm)

NOx Emission Control Areas (NECAs):
- North American ECA: effective 1 Aug 2012
- US Caribbean Sea ECA: effective 1 Jan 2014
- Baltic Sea and North Sea NECA: effective 1 Jan 2021
- Mediterranean Sea NECA: effective 1 Jan 2025

Compliance methods for Tier III:
- Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR)
- Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR)
- LNG or other gas fuels (inherently low-NOx)

EIAPP Certificate (Engine International Air Pollution Prevention) required for each engine.

LOOKUP INSTRUCTION: To determine the NOx limit:
1. Identify ship construction date → Tier level
2. Identify engine rated speed (rpm) → specific limit value
3. If in ECA and post-2016 construction → Tier III applies

=== MARPOL Annex VI Reg 14: Sulphur Content Limits ===
=== Applicable to: All ships using fuel oil ===

Global sulphur content limits:
  Before 1 Jan 2012: ≤4.50% m/m
  1 Jan 2012 – 31 Dec 2019: ≤3.50% m/m
  1 Jan 2020 onwards (IMO 2020): ≤0.50% m/m

ECA/SECA sulphur content limits:
  Before 1 Jul 2010: ≤1.50% m/m
  1 Jul 2010 – 31 Dec 2014: ≤1.00% m/m
  1 Jan 2015 onwards: ≤0.10% m/m

CURRENT LIMITS (2020 onwards):
  GLOBAL: ≤0.50% sulphur by mass
  INSIDE ECA/SECA: ≤0.10% sulphur by mass
  EU ports: ≤0.10% (EU Directive)

Sulphur Emission Control Areas (SECAs):
  1. Baltic Sea area
  2. North Sea area (including English Channel)
  3. North American ECA (200 nm from US/Canada coast)
  4. United States Caribbean Sea ECA

Compliance options:
  - Low-sulphur fuel (VLSFO): use fuel with ≤0.50% (global) or ≤0.10% (ECA)
  - Scrubber (EGCS): exhaust gas cleaning system — can use high-sulphur fuel
  - Alternative fuels (LNG, methanol): must achieve equivalent SOx reduction

Documentation:
  - Bunker Delivery Note (BDN): must state sulphur content, retained 3 years
  - MARPOL representative sample: sealed by supplier, retained 12 months
  - Fuel changeover procedure documented when entering/leaving ECA

text:
=== MARPOL Annex I Reg 15: Oily Bilge Water Discharge ===
=== Applicable to: Ships of 400 GT and above ===

General sea areas (outside special areas):
  - Oil content of effluent: ≤15 ppm (parts per million)
  - Ship must be en route (proceeding)
  - Effluent processed through approved oily water separator (OWS)
  - Oil content monitor (OCM) in operation
  - No dilution of oily water to meet 15 ppm limit

Special areas (Annex I):
  - Same ≤15 ppm limit applies
  - Additionally: 15 ppm bilge alarm MUST be fitted
  - Automatic stopping device to prevent discharge when >15 ppm

Ships of <400 GT:
  - Must retain oil residues on board for discharge to port reception facilities
  - OR use approved OWS achieving ≤15 ppm

Ships of 10,000 GT and above (additional):
  - Oil filtering equipment required (not just OWS)
  - Oil content meter with automatic recording

SPECIAL AREA LIST (Annex I):
  Mediterranean Sea, Baltic Sea, Black Sea, Red Sea, Gulf of Aden,
  Antarctic area, North West European waters, Oman area of Arabian Sea,
  Southern South African waters

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- 15 ppm is a MAXIMUM — not a target
- Oil Record Book Part I must record all bilge water operations
- OWS must be type-approved to IMO MEPC.107(49)

LOOKUP INSTRUCTION:
1. Identify ship tonnage (≥400 GT, ≥10,000 GT)
2. Identify location (general sea area or special area)
3. All ships: ≤15 ppm via approved OWS

text:
=== MARPOL Annex I Reg 34 (+ Reg 29): Oil Tanker Cargo Area Discharge ===
=== Applicable to: Oil tankers of 150 GT and above ===

Outside special areas — discharge of oily mixtures from cargo tank area:
  - Ship must be en route (proceeding)
  - Instantaneous rate of discharge: ≤30 litres per nautical mile
  - Total quantity discharged per voyage: ≤1/30,000 of total cargo capacity
  - Distance from nearest land: >50 nautical miles
  - ODME system in operation during discharge
  - Slop tank system in operation

Inside special areas — discharge:
  - PROHIBITED — no discharge of oil or oily mixture from cargo area
  - Must retain all residues for shore reception facilities

The 1/30,000 rule explained:
  Total oil discharged during a ballast voyage must not exceed 1/30,000
  of the total cargo capacity.
  Example: Tanker with 100,000 m³ capacity → max 3.33 m³ total discharge.

ODME system requirements:
  - Continuously monitors oil content of effluent
  - Automatically stops discharge when exceeding permitted level
  - Type-approved by Administration
  - Connected to automatic stopping device

Special areas (Annex I): Mediterranean, Baltic, Black Sea, Red Sea,
Gulf of Aden, Antarctic, North West European waters, Oman area, S. Africa

LOOKUP INSTRUCTION:
1. Is the ship in a special area? If YES → discharge PROHIBITED
2. If outside special area → ≤30 L/nm, ≤1/30000 cargo, >50 nm from land

=== MARPOL Annex IV Reg 11: Sewage Discharge Standards ===
=== Applicable to: Ships of 400 GT and above, or carrying >15 persons ===

Treated sewage (approved sewage treatment plant):
  - Distance from nearest land: >3 nautical miles
  - Effluent must meet MEPC.227(64) standards
  - Treated sewage not producing visible floating solids
  - Treated sewage not causing discolouration of water

Comminuted and disinfected sewage:
  - Distance from nearest land: >3 nautical miles
  - Using approved comminuting and disinfecting system

Untreated sewage:
  - Distance from nearest land: >12 nautical miles
  - Ship proceeding at not less than 4 knots
  - Rate of discharge approved by Administration
  - Sewage NOT stored in holding tank (gradual discharge)

Baltic Sea Special Area (effective 1 Jun 2023 for new ships):
  - Passenger ships: must have approved sewage treatment plant meeting
    nitrogen (N) ≤20 mg/L and phosphorus (P) ≤1.0 mg/L standards
  - New passenger ships (keel laid ≥1 Jun 2021): immediately
  - Existing passenger ships: by 1 Jun 2023
  - Cargo ships: same as general requirements

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Holding tank discharge: must be at moderate rate when ship en route
- Port reception facilities must be used when in port
- Sewage mixed with wastes covered by other Annexes → stricter rules apply

  Outside special area, <3 nm from land: PROHIBITED
  Inside special area, >12 nm from land: PERMITTED (en route)

  Outside special area, >12 nm from land: PERMITTED (en route)

  Outside special area, >12 nm: PERMITTED

ALL other garbage (plastics, domestic waste, cooking oil, incinerator ash, etc.):

ABSOLUTE PROHIBITION:
  - Plastics: NEVER discharged at sea (including synthetic ropes, fishing nets)
  - Domestic waste: NEVER discharged at sea
  - Cooking oil: NEVER discharged at sea
  - Incinerator ash: NEVER discharged at sea

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Garbage Record Book required for ships ≥400 GT or carrying >15 persons
- Garbage Management Plan required for ships ≥100 GT

title: SOLAS III Reg 21: Passenger Ship Survival Craft and Rescue Boat Requirements
breadcrumb: SOLAS > Chapter III > Regulation 21 > Passenger ship LSA
text:
=== SOLAS III Reg 21: Passenger Ship Survival Craft Requirements ===
=== Applicable to: Passenger ships ===

Survival craft (Reg 21.1):
  Required equipment:
  - Partially enclosed lifeboats on EACH SIDE: capacity for ≥37.5% of total persons
  - Additional liferafts: capacity for ≥25% of total persons
  - TOTAL survival craft capacity: ≥100% of total persons from EACH SIDE
  - At least ONE rescue boat (may be a lifeboat)
  Additional requirements:
  - Liferafts on each side served by launching appliances
  - Marine Evacuation Systems (MES) may substitute for liferafts
  - Short international voyages: may use liferafts for 100% + additional 25%

Ro-ro passenger ships (Reg 21.1.5):
  Required equipment:
  - Survival craft for 100% on each side
  - At least ONE rescue boat on each side (total ≥2)
  - Fast rescue boat required if ≥500 persons on board

Rescue boats (Reg 21.2):
  - At least 1 rescue boat
  - Must be capable of being launched within 5 minutes
  - If >500 persons: fast rescue boat required

LOOKUP INSTRUCTION: First identify passenger count and voyage type,
then find matching capacity requirements.

title: SOLAS III Reg 31: Cargo Ship Survival Craft and Rescue Boat Requirements

=== SOLAS III Reg 31: Cargo Ship Survival Craft Requirements ===
=== Applicable to: Cargo ships ===

Lifeboats (Reg 31.1.1-31.1.2):
  Required equipment:
  - One or more lifeboats on EACH SIDE: capacity for 100% of total persons
  - OR a free-fall lifeboat at the stern: capacity for 100% of total persons

Liferafts (Reg 31.1.3-31.1.4):
  Required equipment:
  - Ships with lifeboats on each side: liferafts for ≥100% total persons
  - Ships with free-fall lifeboat only: additional liferafts for ≥100% on each side
  - At least ONE davit-launched liferaft (SOLAS III/31.1.4)
  Additional requirements:
  - Ships ≥85m: at least one davit-launched liferaft per side
  - Total liferaft capacity: 200% of total persons (when transferable)

Rescue boats (Reg 31.2):
  - At least 1 rescue boat
  - May be one of the lifeboats

KEY REQUIREMENTS SUMMARY:
  | Configuration | Lifeboat | Liferaft | Davit-launched |
  | Lifeboats each side | 100% each side | ≥100% total | ≥1 |
  | Free-fall stern only | 100% total | ≥100% each side | ≥1 |

IMPORTANT: Free-fall lifeboat does NOT exempt the davit-launched liferaft requirement.

LOOKUP INSTRUCTION: First identify lifeboat configuration (each side or free-fall),
then determine liferaft requirements.

title: SOLAS IV Reg 7-14: GMDSS Equipment Requirements by Sea Area
text:
=== SOLAS IV Reg 7-14: GMDSS Equipment by Sea Area ===
=== Applicable to: All SOLAS ships ===

Sea Area A1 (VHF range, ~20-30 nm from coast):
  Required equipment:
  - VHF radio with DSC (Digital Selective Calling)
  - NAVTEX receiver (or EGC/HF MSI)
  - Radar transponder (SART) or AIS-SART: at least 2
  - EPIRB (406 MHz, satellite): 1, float-free
  - 2-way VHF portable radios: at least 3

Sea Area A2 (MF range, ~100-150 nm from coast):
  Required equipment:
  - All A1 equipment PLUS:
  - MF radio with DSC
  - MF radiotelephony watch receiver

Sea Area A3 (INMARSAT geostationary satellite coverage, ~70°N-70°S):
  Required equipment:
  - All A1+A2 equipment PLUS:
  - INMARSAT ship earth station (SES) — OR — MF/HF radio with DSC
  - EGC receiver (if INMARSAT) or HF MSI receiver

Sea Area A4 (polar regions, beyond INMARSAT coverage):
  Required equipment:
  - All A1+A2 equipment PLUS:
  - MF/HF radio installation with DSC
  - HF direct-printing telegraphy
  - HF MSI equipment

ALL areas — mandatory equipment:
  - EPIRB 406 MHz (float-free, GNSS-equipped)
  - SART or AIS-SART: ≥2
  - 2-way VHF: ≥3 (≥2 for cargo ships <300 GT)
  - VHF DSC watch on Ch 70 (automatic)

LOOKUP INSTRUCTION: First identify sea area (A1/A2/A3/A4),
then look up required equipment for that area.

title: SOLAS V Reg 19: Navigation Equipment Requirements by Ship Size
breadcrumb: SOLAS > Chapter V > Regulation 19 > Navigation equipment
text:
=== SOLAS V Reg 19: Navigation Equipment by Ship Size ===
=== Applicable to: All SOLAS ships ===

All ships (Reg 19.2.1):
  - Magnetic compass (or equivalent)
  - Pelorus or compass bearing device
  - Means of correcting heading and bearing
  - Nautical charts and nautical publications (ECDIS or paper)
  - Receiver for GNSS or terrestrial positioning
  - Radar reflector (if <150 GT and practicable)
  - Sound reception system (if enclosed bridge)
  - Telephone to emergency steering position

Ships ≥150 GT (Reg 19.2.2):
  Additional equipment:
  - Echo-sounder

Ships ≥300 GT (Reg 19.2.3):
  Additional equipment:
  - 9 GHz radar (X-band)
  - AIS (Automatic Identification System)
  - Electronic plotting aid (EPA or equivalent)

Ships ≥500 GT (Reg 19.2.4):
  Additional equipment:
  - Gyrocompass (or equivalent)
  - Gyrocompass heading repeater (at steering position)
  - Gyrocompass bearing repeater
  - Rudder angle indicator
  - RPM indicator (for each propeller)
  - Rate-of-turn indicator

Ships ≥3,000 GT (Reg 19.2.5):
  Additional equipment:
  - Second 3 GHz radar (S-band)
  - Automatic tracking aid (ATA) or ARPA

Ships ≥10,000 GT (Reg 19.2.6):
  Additional equipment:
  - ARPA (Automatic Radar Plotting Aid) — on both radars
  - Heading or track control system

Ships ≥50,000 GT (Reg 19.2.7):
  Additional equipment:
  - Rate-of-turn indicator
  - Speed and distance measuring device (through water and over ground)

ECDIS requirement (Reg 19.2.10):
  - Ships ≥10,000 GT on international voyages: ECDIS required
  - Ships ≥3,000 GT: ECDIS required (phased-in by 2018)
  - ECDIS counts as chart carriage requirement

VDR/S-VDR (SOLAS V/18):
  - Ships ≥3,000 GT (built after 2002): VDR required
  - Cargo ships 3,000-20,000 GT (older): S-VDR acceptable
  - All passenger ships: VDR required

LOOKUP INSTRUCTION: First identify ship tonnage, then look up cumulative
equipment requirements (each tier includes all lower-tier requirements).

title: STCW Reg VIII & STCW Code A-VIII/1: Seafarer Rest Hours Requirements
text:
=== STCW Reg VIII / Code A-VIII/1: Seafarer Rest Hours ===
=== Applicable to: All watchkeeping personnel on STCW ships ===

Minimum rest hours:
  In any 24-hour period: ≥10 hours of rest
  In any 7-day period: ≥77 hours of rest

Rest period structure:
  - May be divided into no more than TWO periods
  - One of the two periods must be at least 6 hours long
  - The interval between consecutive rest periods must not exceed 14 hours

Exceptions (limited):
  - Emergency drills: may be conducted during rest hours
  - Call-out for safety reasons: rest hours may be interrupted
  - Musters and fire-fighting drills prescribed by national law
  - After interruption: compensatory rest period must be provided

Additional requirements:
  - Records of daily hours of rest: maintained and endorsed
  - Master must post watchkeeping schedule
  - Records available for inspection by PSC

ILO MLC 2006 alignment:
  - Maximum working hours alternative: ≤14 hours in any 24-hour period,
    ≤72 hours in any 7-day period
  - Flag State chooses either rest hours OR working hours system

Young seafarers (<18 years):
  - Night work prohibited (between 2100-0600)
  - Maximum 8 hours work per day

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- PSC frequently checks rest hour records — non-compliance is a deficiency
- Records must be in the working language of the ship AND in English
- Port State may detain a ship if crew is clearly fatigued

LOOKUP INSTRUCTION:
1. Minimum rest: ≥10h per 24h period, ≥77h per 7-day period
2. Split: max 2 periods, one ≥6h, gap ≤14h
